Title: 2025-04-01-final-final-FINAL-V2.go
Description:
Some very important news on the future of the show in this episode. You'll get answers to important questions like:

  What does the future of the show look like? Who are the next, big ticket, guests? What's a SegFault? Why does my knee hurt? Why do fools fall in love? Does this look infected to you?  Any many more. So definitely make a point of listening to this episode... all the way to the end, too.

 There's no transcription for this episode, as it's all breaking news and I didn't have the time to get one completed before the time of release.

 Show Notes Welcome friends to The Modern .NET Show; the premier .NET podcast, focusing entirely on the knowledge, tools, and frameworks that all .NET developers should have in their toolbox. We are the go-to podcast for .NET developers worldwide, and I am your host: Jamie "GaProgMan" Taylor.

 In this episode, I'll talk you through a slight change of direction for the show. But more on that in a moment. Let's listen to the intro music for a little longer before I wrap up this intro.

 Anyway, without further ado, let's sit back, open up a terminal, type in `go mod init github.com/golang-show` and we'll dive into...

 Supporting the Show If you find this episode useful in any way, please consider supporting the show by either leaving a review (check our review page for ways to do that), sharing the episode with a friend or colleague, buying the host a coffee, or considering becoming a Patron of the show.

 Full Show Notes There are no full show notes for this episode, friends. I'm sorry for that, but it's the nature of the game when you're releasing breaking news.

 I'll try and get a transcription completed in the next few days, so watch out for that.

 Music Used In This Episode This contains some copyright free music during the interstitials. Each of the pieces of music (linked below) were created by some incredibly highly skilled invididuals. If you liked the music we used, check out links to the them below:

  "Ascend (sped up)" by Alex-Productions "Golden" by HoobeZa "Mellow" by HoobeZa  Supporting the show:  Leave a rating or review Buy the show a coffee Become a patron  Getting in Touch:  Via the contact page Joining the Discord  Remember to rate and review the show on  Apple Podcasts, Podchaser, or wherever you find your podcasts, this will help the show's audience grow. Or you can just share the show with a friend.

 And don't forget to reach out via our Contact page. We're very interested in your opinion of the show, so please get in touch.

 You can support the show by making a monthly donation on the show's Patreon page at: https://www.patreon.com/TheDotNetCorePodcast.

Title: Two Attacks on Naive Tree Hashes
Description:
If you're building a tree hash,‚Äãalso known as a Merkle tree and you want it to have the same
security properties as a cryptographic hash like SHA-3 or BLAKE3, there are a
couple of "attacks" you need to know about. Here's a naive recursive tree hash
based on SHA-3 in Python, which turns out to be vulnerable to these
attacks:‚ÄãDividing the length by 2 at each level of the tree like this is a
shortcut, but the resulting tree structure isn't great, because we have to
know the final input length to figure out where any of the leaf or subtree
boundaries are. That's no problem in these examples, but in practice most
hash functions need to be able to "stream" long inputs in a loop
without knowing the final length until the end. A better splitting rule for
real tree hashes is to make the left side as large as possible as long as
it's a power-of-2. See the BLAKE3 paper, particularly sections 2.1 and
5.1.2, and also Binary Numeral Trees.

Title: Sunsetting openSNP - a personal retrospective
Description: As this blog post is being published, we are sending out emails to all openSNP users with some news: OpenSNP will be turned off ‚Äì and with that also delete all the data stored on it ‚Äì on April 30, 2025. Given that the project has been part of my...

Title: Unpacking Dijkstra‚Äôs Note on ‚ÄúWhy Numbering Should Start at Zero‚Äù
Description: Edsger W. Dijkstra wrote a famous note titled ‚ÄúWhy numbering should start at zero‚Äù This three-page handwritten document is often cited in discussions about why indexing in programming languages should start at zero. While his reasoning is relatively straightforward, the document lacks the structure and examples needed to fully grasp it‚Äîat least for me‚Äîwithout resorting to pen and paper. As a result, I decided to read it thoroughly and unpack his reasoning into explicit arguments, expressed in my own words and illustrated with examples.

Title: How to fix the Missing Custom Models bug
Description:
This is a quick fix to a problem I experienced with Open WebUI, which was that custom models were not showing in the models list. There was nothing in the documentation or in the issues pointing to a solution. I decided to open a new issue 4 days ago and today the user @dcolley gave the missing information and it worked.
For some reason, custom models are not working when you use Direct Connections.

Title: Bootstrapping ranking models with an LLM judge - Emir's blog
Description:
I use 500 Hacker News (HN) titles and an LLM to derive an article ranking
model from a user supplied preference description. The LLM supplies the
labelled data, whilst Ridge regression and cheap sentence transformer
embedding provides the features. The surrogate has 0.74 Spearman correlation
with the LLM labels, which is remarkable given that the experiment is entirely
unoptimised.

Title: Stop syncing everything
Description: Discover Graft, an open-source transactional storage engine built to solve the challenges of syncing data at the edge. Inspired by lessons from SQLSync, Graft enables lazy, partial, and strongly consistent replication‚Äîallowing edge applications to sync only the data they need, exactly when they need it.
